questions.question_text:
You have a collection of reports for the HR department of your company.
You need to create a visualization for the HR department that shows a historic employee counts and predicts trends during the next six months.
Which type of visualization should you use?

discussion.content: Correct Answer: C , line chart

Ans c - is correct that is 
 line chart and then use the forecast option in the Visualization property window

Selected Answer: C
Answer is C
on exam 7/11/22

A. key influencers helps you to understand the factors that drive a metric you are interested in
B. ribbon chart discover which data category has the highest rank (largest value).
---C. line chart present trends over time Correct
D. scatter chart displays outliers

Selected Answer: C
Line chart

discussion.content: should be B. I created the median measure MEDIAN(EmployeeTable[Salary]) and used it in the visual, it gave me another bar for each employee not a reference median line. To create that I had to use the analytics pane and median from it. Then I got a reference line at 50%.
Has anyone sat for the PL-300 exam within the past two months from Sept 1, 2022?

A is correct Tested. It means to add a median line from visual analytics. When adding the median line, PowerBI considers by default the first measure of the clustered bar chart. However, you can add multiple measures in the value section, so you need to choose which measure to use for calculating the median. That's why it's mentioned in the answer "by using the Salary measure"

questions.question_text:
Note: This question is part of a series of questions that present the same scenario. Each question in the series contains a unique solution that might meet the stated goals. Some question sets might have more than one correct solution, while others might not have a correct solution.
After you answer a question in this scenario, you will NOT be able to return to it. As a result, these questions will not appear in the review screen.
You have a clustered bar chart that contains a measure named Salary as the value and a field named Employee as the axis. Salary is present in the data as numerical amount representing US dollars.
You need to create a reference line to show which employees are above the median salary.
Solution: You create a median line by using the Salary measure.
Does this meet the goal?

choices.B: Create a button for each business question and set the action type to Bookmark.
choices.A: Create a text box for each business question and insert a link.
choices.C: Create a Power Apps visual that contains a drop-down list. The drop-down list will contain the business questions.

questions.question_text:
You are developing a sales report that will have multiple pages. Each page will answer a different business question.
You plan to have a menu page that will show all the business questions.
You need to ensure that users can click each business question and be directed to the page where the question is answered. The solution must ensure that the menu page will work when deployed to any workspace.
What should you include on the menu page?

comments.content: It should be B

The question is not about efficiency. Moreover powerapps visual will have an impact when deployed to other environments and links may change. So clearly only option that make sense is Bookmarking pages.
If it's B, it means that if we have new questions, we need another button and on and on, that's not efficient

discussion.content:
I think B.
https://insightsoftware.com/blog/how-to-create-a-bookmark-in-power-bi/#:~:text=Go%20to%20the%20Format%20Image,specific%20bookmark%20of%20your%20choice.
Ans should be B - Bookmarks work well in such scenarios.

The solution is in the question statetment: You plan to have a menu page that will show all the business questions.
You need to ensure that users can click each business question and be directed to the page where the question is answered. therfore, a dropdown will NOT show each question and users cannot click on each question. Creating bookmark buttons will satisfy this requirement
Should be B

Selected Answer: B
Answer should be B

Selected Answer: B
B is the correct answer.
B is correct

B is the correct answer.

Power BI enables data insights and better decision-making, while Power Apps enables everyone to build and use apps that connect to business data. Using the Power Apps visual, you can pass context-aware data to a canvas app, which updates in real time as you make changes to your report. Now, your app users can derive business insights and take actions from right within their Power BI reports and dashboards.
https://docs.microsoft.com/en-us/powerapps/maker/canvas-apps/powerapps-custom-visual

Definitely B. When you create a bookmark, the following elements are saved with the bookmark:

- The current page
- Filters
- Slicers, including slicer type (for example, dropdown or list) and slicer state
- Visual selection state (such as cross-highlight filters)
- Sort order
- Drill location
- Visibility of an object (by using the Selection pane)
- The focus or Spotlight modes of any visible object

questions.answer_description:
If you find yourself unable to navigate to an object or visual while using a keyboard, it may be because the report author has decided to hide that object from the tab order. Report authors commonly hide decorative objects from the tab order. If you find that you cannot tab through a report in a logical manner, you should contact the report author. Report authors can set the tab order for objects and visuals.
Reference:
https://docs.microsoft.com/en-us/power-bi/create-reports/desktop-accessibility-consuming-tools

comments.content: https://docs.microsoft.com/en-us/power-bi/create-reports/desktop-accessibility-consuming-tools

discussion.content:
Correct

Source: https://datasavvy.me/2018/12/26/tab-order-enhances-power-bi-report-accessibility/
Correct answer. TAB ORDER

questions.question_text:
You are developing a report page. Some users will navigate the report by using a keyboard, and some users will consume the report by using a screen reader.
You need to ensure that the users can consume the content on a report page in a logical order.
What should you configure in Microsoft Power BI Desktop?

Tested and confirmed: C and D. By default, when the Whole number is selected as the datatype, Power BI will Summarize the values. To get it to the screen shot though you'll need to click on the 'Advanced' option which is not displayed and select 'None' under Summarized By. Once you change the Summarized by to 'None' and use the field in the table visual, it will show distinct values.

For the first one, it seems that there could be 2 possibilities depending on how you populate the table visual. If you drag and drop the StoreID onto the Values box in the Visualizations pane, you get a Count of StoreID, hence answer (A). But if you click StoreID from the Fields pane, you get a distinct list of StoreID, hence answer (C).

For second one, due to the bi-directional filter on the relationship, it's a general consensus, answer (D).

discussion.content:
This is a tricky one. 
a) It does not show the sum but the distinct values in the table because it has a relationship
b) Filters all the tables on which it is related to

The first box must be "List of the distinct StoreID values". How come so many people here said the first box is D (sum of the StoreID value)? I can't believe someone even said "tested" and come up with this answer. 
If the id column has a relationship with other table in the model
- the summarization feature will not be applied. 
- when drag into a table visual, only distinct value will be displayed.
It will only be D if there is no relationship for StoreID column with other table. However, we can clearly see that there is a many to one relationship between the Sales and Store table by using the StoreID column.

The second box should be "Only to the Sales table", straight forward.

discussion.content:
I tested this a few mins ago, using SQL 2019 developer edition on my local, I created the SALES and STORE tables, and also added the fields as shown in the screenshots. I created 17 stores, then created 9 sales records with 3 records each per store. The STOREID is integer type.

Imported the tables using POWEBI, added a blank table, and just dragged the STOREID fields IN the SALES table, what I got was a DISTINCT LIST of the STOREIDs.

I also at the settings of the STOREID field in the VALUES section and the default behavior is "DONT SUMMARIZE"


ANSWER: C&D

FWIW: "My version of POWERBI is "2.93.981.0 64-bit (May, 2021)"
My tests showed that Power BI automatically sums integer values BUT if the integer values are used in a relationship between two tables it will show a distinct list of the integers.

comments.content: This is the best answer

discussion.content:
Tested: C and D
1.When you have a 1 to * relationship between Sales and Store the table visual shows distinct StoreIds when populated by StoreId column from Sales table
2. Due to the fact that there is a bi directional link between Sales and Customer the page filter set by SalesId =1 filters two tables : Sales and Customer
In order to filter other tables except Customer it would require cross-filter direction:both. Tested
The answer is C and D, since the store ID is used as a key for creating a relation between store and sales table, the Power BI doesn't summarize it.

there is a 1-1 relationship between Sales and customer which is bidirectional and will cause the filter to propagate to customer.

discussion.content: It would have sigma sign in data model if is set to summarize, this way it will show distinct ID's. Have tested it.

comments.content: Wrong- If there is a relationship default sum is turned off.

discussion.content:
By default, whole number, decimal number, and fixed decimal number are set to Sum
D & D

D, A. By default, whole numbers are summed. Sales table has cross filter with with both Product (Single) and Customer table (both). Customer table also has cross filter with Associated Product table (Single). The filter on the Sales table will impact all these tables and other related tables.

First question: answer should be C. 
Second question: The filter Sales[StoreID] = 1 is applied to Sales Table, any table if it is linked with sales table, the rows should be filtered too. Why the answer is not A?

If the filter is Store[StoreID] = 1, feel that D make sense.

comments.content: Maybe select D because of this kind of abnormal data model?? Really don't know how it works.

The data model looks wierd. 
1. The cross filter directly is from Product to Sales. Normally it should be from master data table or dimension table to fact table. Here is opposite. 
2. The Cardinality of Customer and Sales tables is 1 to 1. Normally should be 1 to many.

Not sure if it is special for this question.

discussion.content: The correct answer is C & D

comments.content: Once add 1 to many relationship between store and sales, the Summarization of storeID field in sales table change from default value (Default value is count when I test it) to Don't summarize. So the first question is C.
Correct my comment: Store ID is from sales table, so the answer for the first question is C.

Test it: The one to many relationship from Store to Sales doesn’t allow duplicate records in store table. It will display a list of all the StoreID values (also StoreiIDs are distinct) no matter if the store is in sales table or not. B is also correct for the first question.

discussion.content:
Q1: Sum of the StoreID values. Because the default summarization is sum for data types that are whole number.
Q2: the Sales table and the Customer table. Because filters only pass on to the customer table while other connections to the sales table.

comments.content: if the data type is whole number, the default summarization is sum
I got the same situation as you do. Data tye is whole number and default setting on my Power BI Desktop is Summarize by Count.

discussion.content: Does anybody know why the default summarization is sum? When I test this in Power BI Desktop the default summarization is count. I'm also seeing other people say the default for them is don't summarize.
I think there is a problem with that model, because there is a filter direction from Sales (*) -> (1) Product, wich isn't possible

comments.content: Also tested this with a table where the ID isn't unique. It returns a list of distinct IDs. I think everyone is (rightly) assuming the StoreID values are unique
my bad, its from the sales table. It is the distinct values then. It should be C
thats right
I thought so too at first but no, because data type is Whole Number - you can see it on the right side hand of the model.

discussion.content: why first answer is not c, list of all distinct storeid values

comments.content: This makes more sense

discussion.content: There is no StoreID in table Customer, only Store. Therefore, to me it doesn't make sense the customer table would be filtered as well, so I'd say D and B
The answer is B & D
I think is list of distinct store id values and filter both Sales and Customer tables
My answer is "List of Distinct Store ID values" and Filter both Sales and Customer tables.
D and D is correct.
